summary:
Headline:
AMD delivered a strong Q4 2025 with record revenue of $9.2 billion, up 36% YoY, driven by broad demand across data center AI, server, and PC segments. Net income rose 31%, and free cash flow more than tripled, highlighting robust profitability and cash generation.

Growth & revenue drivers:
- Data center revenue grew 22% YoY to a record $4.3 billion, led by ramp of Instinct MI350 GPUs and server share gains.
- Fifth Gen EPYC server CPUs accounted for nearly half of EPYC revenue, with strong adoption in hyperscalers and enterprises.
- Hyperscalers launched 160+ EPYC-powered cloud instances this quarter; total public EPYC cloud instances increased ~50% YoY to 1,350+.
- Enterprise adoption of EPYC servers accelerated sharply, with 175+ Gen EPYC platforms available from major OEMs.
- Large new wins secured across Fortune 500 tech, telecom, financial services, retail, streaming, social, and automotive verticals.
- Ryzen and Instinct processor sales also contributed significantly to revenue growth.

Margins / profitability:
- Net income increased 31% YoY, reflecting strong operational leverage from higher revenue.
- Free cash flow more than tripled, indicating improved cash conversion and capital efficiency.
- Specific margin percentages were not disclosed in the truncated remarks.

Guidance & outlook:
- AMD expects continued strong cloud demand as hyperscalers scale AI workloads, driving larger CPU build-outs in coming quarters.
- The company highlighted AI as a powerful new catalyst for server business growth.
- No specific forward guidance figures were provided in the available remarks.
- Upcoming investor events include a financial analyst day and presentations at major technology conferences.

Risks / watchpoints:
- Forward-looking statements subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially.
- Competitive dynamics in server and AI markets remain a key factor.
- Execution on scaling AI-related compute capacity and maintaining share gains in hyperscalers and enterprises will be critical.
- No explicit risks detailed in the truncated CFO remarks.
